subject: Business
title: Bonds: Lending Money for Interest
description: A micro-lesson that makes Bonds: Lending Money for Interest usable.

hook.text: When you buy a US Treasury bond, you're lending money to the government. They pay you back with interest.

buildup.text: A bond is an IOU: the issuer borrows your money, pays regular interest (coupon), and returns principal at maturity.

discovery.text: Bonds are rated from AAA (safest) to junk. Higher risk bonds pay higher interest to attract buyers.

twist.text: When interest rates rise, existing bond prices fall. Investors sell old bonds yielding less for new ones yielding more.

climax.text: In 2022, bonds lost 13% â€” the worst year since 1842 â€” as the Fed rapidly raised rates.

punchline.text: Bonds are safe until interest rates move. Then they're a reminder that 'safe'.

quiz.question: What happens to existing bond prices when interest rates rise?
options: Existing bond prices fall because new bonds offer higher yields
Bond prices rise with interest rates
Bond prices are unaffected by interest rate changes
